segments.text: Now, beside Francis Shepherd, what other oceanographers would you cite as having some major impact on your career?

Well, I think in the 50s, there were... Well, when I first began oceanography, the dominant person in the field was Harold Spurge, a physical oceanographer, so he didn't really affect me too much directly, but he was sort of the dean of oceanography.
And in the 50s, there developed a triumvirate
oceanographers in the US, and these were Roger Vell and Columbus Islin and Morris Ewing, the directors of three major laboratories.
And personally, Roger Vell had much influence upon my career because we were very personally involved in many things, though we never did publish together.
We were involved in expeditions.
Columbus Houston had almost no direct influence upon me, but Morris Ewing had a great influence by his work at the Lamont Observatory.
And he, to my way of thinking, was the preeminent sort of marine geologist of my generation.
It's too bad he's not around for you to interview, but he had enormous impact upon marine geology and geophysics.
So, as a person who was not a colleague of mine, not a direct colleague, he certainly had great influence upon my thinking and work.
other people who had considerable influence upon my work, in geology, for example, Harry Hess, I knew very well, and he was, his ideas were very close to mine.
We more or less thought along the same lines.
And at Lamont, Bruce Hazen was always, his interests were very close to mine.
His influence was very important.
Now at Scripps, I guess Bill Menard and I worked together.
H.W.
Menard.
He and I, of course, published together.
I first bought him into oceanography and employed him at the Navy Electronics Laboratory.
My other colleagues there in the Navy, notably Robert Dill, he's now director of the West Indies Laboratory, and David Moore, who's now chief scientist of the Deep Sea Drilling Project, and

Edwin Hamilton I guess were very important colleagues and influences I guess these were the perhaps the the major people earlier on of course Henry Stetson's work was important but his most of his ideas were rather classical and
where he was involved in ideas about the continental shelf of the slope that I was interested in disproving, rather than...
But... Well, the whole... Well, I think preeminent perhaps marine geologist, a person who I knew very well,
had much contact with, and perhaps the preeminent marine geologist worldwide, was Kynan, Philip Kynan, in the Netherlands.
And his whole grasp of the subject was outstanding, and he had an important influence upon my thinking and work.
He particularly
Of course, he developed a concept of turbidity currents and did a great job with this.

I more or less tried to follow his model in my work on impact structures and astroplanes because I originally thought that if I published one paper I'd done my job and I should forget about it and go on to something else.
He published great groups of paper, often repeating himself on turbidity currents, and he became a sort of a great protagonist of the idea.

Well, I more or less did the same thing in terms of astroblemes, that as long as I was being cast in the role of being the protagonist, I might as well live up to that role and try to promote these things, even to the point of being
a very aggressive advocate of ideas, ideas I wasn't too sure of.
But nevertheless, you're cast in this role, and you have to react by trying to defend or promote that point of view.
And so in this regard, I more or less tried to follow the model of Philip Koonin and his great protagonism in favor of turbidity currents.
So I would say that his works and his philosophy of life was kind of important.
what I attempted to do.
Of course, I should mention K.O.
Emery, too, since he and I were classmates and roommates for many years, and we collaborated in the early years, and his influence was very important.
Several people have suggested that possibly one of the problems that oceanography faced in the period between about 46 to about 53 or 54, and perhaps a little later, was that
I may use it collectively, Scripps, Woods Hole, and Lamont, perhaps had too much of a role in directing oceanographic research.
That is, that they perhaps had research funds too tightly held.
Was this your experience?
Would you agree with that?
Well, I agree that they had funds very tightly held, because they were...
They were both the receiver and the giver.
I mean, their oceanographers would go to Washington and occupy the seats of the people giving grants within ONR, like Roger Revelle, and people of that category.
I'm not sure this was bad.
This may have been a good thing.
I really can't assess that because

oceanography did need some focal points and it needed large amounts of money to support ships and oceanographers are a group of scientists of various disciplines and backgrounds whose common bond is needing a ship and if you look at
The failure in the earlier years of French oceanography, it is based upon the fact that the French people and scientists are, as they are reported to be, rather prima donnas.
And they couldn't get together.
And there was never, every French scientist of himself was not big enough to justify having a ship.
But he couldn't collaborate with his other people, you know, in associated fields, to get a nucleus large enough to support a ship.
But by having Woods Hole and Lamont and Scripps in this major role as being the focal points, this really got oceanography off the ground.
And so I would suggest, in spite of the fact there's a certain amount of inbreeding between people going back and forth to Washington, it probably was a good thing.
I think it's fair to say that, for example, Ewing and Ravel had different personalities.
From what I can read from Bullard and then my interviews with Ravel, I would suggest there are different kinds of people.
Would you hazard to evaluate their contribution, let's say?
Or that is, these people who were important in oceanography, what sort of talent did they bring to oceanography?
Well, in the...

I guess sometime in the late 50s, Time magazine put together a cover story on oceanography, and there was sort of a competition about who should be the cover picture should be on, whether it should be Islin, Revell, or Ewing.
It turned out to be Columbus Islin.
This, in my view, was probably the least appropriate
It should have been Morris Ewing.
And if not Morris Ewing, it should have been Roger Revelle.
Or if not, then thirdly, Columbus Islin as being sort of the Mr. Oceanography of the field.
And why Islin really got this billet, I don't know.
I don't know what was behind it eventually.
But Revelle and Ewing were distinctly different sorts of people.
Roger Val is very charismatic, and he's a great, big, lovable character with many foibles, but also a great and very productive mind.
It always seemed to many of us he was highly disorganized, and it always seemed that he was always...
He was always more interested in what he didn't know than what he did.
I mean, he was always writing papers and working on the edge of his knowledge rather than in those fields where he had a very firm basis.
And so he developed a very sort of broad-spectrum view of oceanography.
And while I would say Morris Ewing was a very intense...

sort of a scientist-scientist, interested in the data himself, interested in, and he held a very tight control over Lamont and over the use of the ship use, and did a fantastic job of data collecting, and he's now credited, for example, in his book about Ewing,

which is a rather misdirected book because it doesn't really hit upon his important contributions, which I would never really deprecate, but it gives him too much credit for plate tectonics, which he in fact didn't believe.
He tried to, well, perhaps he did more to prove it by trying to disprove it because he began to make it, he did have the idea and he didn't accept it and he began to
to collect data, and each time pointing out why this didn't work.
But in the end, of course, his colleagues and themselves, they did a sudden conversion in 67.
They suddenly all threw in the towel and became drifters.
So it was a very interesting development.
And I think Morris Ewing is preeminent as a contribution, as a contributor to the science.
I think his name is on too many papers.
I think he was a lesser contributor.
I mean, sometimes he never could have written all these papers by himself.
And he was, it was difficult for him to
to give his colleagues sufficient freedom and head, I think, to have them do things on their own.
So he's earned too much control of the data.
But, well, maybe not, because the productivity of Lamont and the heroic years of Lamont were doing his regime.
And Lamont will never be able to do what it was under Ewing, but he ran a very tight ship there.

And the people working in that soda environment always, anyone likes to be their own, do their own thing, but he ran a very wonderful operation, a very tight operation, and certainly came out with some marvelous results.
Well, in contrast, Ravel was
extremely successful, of course, in developing scripts.
He eventually, of course, left and went to Harvard.
I don't know the whole story behind that.
I think it was a mistake for him to do so when he was not appointed chancellor of the campus there, but
because I don't see how a man can contribute.
I don't know if he ever became a very good demographer.
Maybe he did, but certainly it's very difficult for a person to suddenly become an expert in a new field.
I'm sure if anyone could do it, Ravel could, but anyway, I was sorry to see him leave the field of oceanography.
There was some objection to Revell taking over Scripps after the war, particularly from, if I understand correctly, Coral Hubbs and Francis Shepard.
Would you have any idea perhaps why?
Was there something about it?
Well, there was a great sort of personality clash around Scripps, and I think there isn't always any sort of center like that, and I think it's to be expected.
Ravel and Shepard operated in different manners.
They were wholly different personalities, and both Shepard and Hubbs were sort of non-mathematically oriented, and so they really didn't speak much the same language.
Ravel was more versed across the board, but he was, uh, and... Ravel ran, he ran sort of slipshod over people, and there's bound to be lots of sparks around.
But I think both, both Hubbs and, uh, and Shepard had sort of a working relationship.
They, they, they were, they were not quiet about it.
They were not uncritical.
And there's lots of, uh,

shots being fired back and forth but i think it was done in sort of a good scientific spirit and or they they didn't tend to bury their differences they there were strong differences i think the the sort of a liaison a certain relationship did survive there and they were both i mean both both shepherd and hubs have been remarkably productive people uh
Ravel was very difficult to work with.
He wanted also to be involved in too many things and too many papers, which he couldn't really handle.
And so if something got in his hands, it might sit there on the bottom of his pile for a year or two.
And Shepard was extremely impatient about getting things out and published.
And Ravel just had too many irons in the fire.
And it was too...
So it was just a different manner of working that made this a very difficult arrangement.

And I think everyone who got directly involved, including myself, had this sort of objection to his method of operating, but at the same time he found him a very delightful person and we really admired his brilliance and his ability to get things done and to inspire people to do things.

I wondered if possibly at that time in oceanography, during those years, is that people such as perhaps Ewing and certainly Revell, people who were primarily movers, were needed to stir up interest or to create interest in this newly developing field.
Would you agree with that?
Yeah, I would agree with a part of it.
I think heroes are made by the conditions.
I mean, if you have a war, you're going to have some heroes.
You're going to have great generals.
And so heroes are sort of product of the situation and the environment.
A hero would always step forward.
I think we're very fortunate in oceanography in having people as, you know, basically as outstanding as Revelle and Ewing in these roles.
See, there was a time when the whole field of geophysics was controlled by two or three Scandinavians.
Then oceanography became under SpareDrip, and then there was this triumvirate for a decade.
Now, of course, oceanography is much too large to identify any people with this amount of influence or power or control.
It's all for the better.
I mean, we no longer have any heroes unless it's some sort of very small sub-discipline.

This is a matter of the size of the field and the way it's evolved and the fact that we perhaps look at things a little more sophisticated and more critical so we tend to get away from the star system which is good.
I mean the star system is probably the bane of existence in certain

fields of hearts and so forth where you have to be a to make it you have to have you have to be a star you have to have a name that people recognize and people know and people only know and recognize so many names so in order to become a in order to become a Cousteau you have to knock off Cousteau you see many many people have tried this they've tried Hans
Hans Haas, other people who have tried to become Cousteaus, but they've never really succeeded in that role, because it is such a tight star system.
But we, in science, we've gotten away from that, which is good.
Now, I realize this is very difficult to do, but in terms of your accomplishments, what would you consider your major accomplishment in oceanography?
In oceanography?
Well, I...
I guess my main contributions would be a sort of a series of contributions to what we now call plate tectonics.
And with playing an initial role, I think it's somewhat, which was mostly done by Harry Hess, but in addition by myself on what is now called seafloor spreading, and some of the basic ideas of
continental drift and the dispersion of continents from Pangea.
I think secondarily probably the most important thing I've done is probably playing an important role in deep submergence with getting the Navy and the country involved in

deep submersibles deep research submersibles deep research submersibles program by the way which is really not hasn't blossomed of late it went to a certain point and it kind of has been in doldrums since but it's uh I guess it's again kind of reprogramming along different lines but uh I haven't uh

My papers generally have been very, very short and brief and papers involving synthesis of ideas and rather than I guess trying to be somewhat interpretive of being ahead of my time trying to work in some frontier and see something a bit differently from other people.
Why, by the way, are submersibles in the doler rooms now?
Well, the... We had hoped, for example, that NOAA would have a substantial mission in submersibles through the must office, and this has not really materialized.
Most of the money in these deep submergence, it takes really public money to
develop these things.
If we had deep submersibles, say, one-tenth of one percent, which goes into airplane development, we would be extremely happy.
Many, many, a whole series of submersibles came off the line for, in the 60s, like the Luminat and various aerospace companies were all building their own.
And none of these have really proved supportable
by private industry.
They involved either direct government subvention or spin-off money from aerospace industry based upon their government contracts.
And so, these have proved to be very expensive.
And for many years, the Mercy Submersibles were getting a great deal of the publicity of oceanography.
maybe more than half, but we're only doing maybe 10% of the work.
So the Navy funding, although I spoke of this level of being several tens of millions of dollars, really hasn't gone into programs that I personally would like.
It's like the Navy oceanography program.
They have a very large oceanography program, but they

appear to redefine what is oceanography and not much of what I would call oceanography comes out of it now I don't know where all the money goes to in deep submersibles but it's really it's evident now that a good bit of it went into the raising Russian submarine but Navy unfortunately has this
When they get a program like this, they write regulations that make things very difficult to operate.
They have safety operations and so forth.
And they get to the point where they really can't have the flexibility to really develop a frontier.
And so then they go into a training mode whereby they train officers to operate submersibles.
and set up a school, and by the time an officer is trained, he's transferred elsewhere, so he doesn't really stay with the program.

In other words, they don't have any, the Navy, among Navy officers, you have, they're trained as line officers to be, and not a specialist, and so they don't really stay with the program and become involved in it.
Most of the useful part, or the best part, I suppose, of the
the Navy Submersible Program is the fact that people retire from the Navy, they spin off people, and these ex-submariners end up as directing Woods Hole Alvin and other programs like that.

In other words, they spin off into the civilian side, and then they specialize and become specialists in deep submergence, rather than within the Navy, because their officers tend to get transferred to new posts, new positions, which keep them as generalists rather than specialists.
The Navy set a role on development in deep-suburban.
This has been rather disappointing.
Most of it's so classified, we don't even know what they're doing.
